bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Colonel Byam, January 14, 1921

div1.p: Carter asks if "The Practice of Medicine in the Tropics," with her father's section on yellow fever, has gone to press. Her father has finished yellow fever work in Peru, but Laura Eugenia Cook Carter, his wife, has died.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Colonel Byam, January 14, 1921

opener.dateline:
The Lonsdale, Apt. 206,
Washington, D. C.
January 14, 1921.

div1.p:
I shouldbbe very grateful if you would tell me whether
The Practice of Medicine in The Tropics, for which my Father,
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter, wrote the Section on
Yellow Fever is yet off the press, and, if so, where it may be
procured in the States.

Father has completed the eradication of yellow fever in
Northern Peru and we are hoping for his return within the next
week or ten days, although there is a chance of his being delayed
on account of having broken his ankle. The detail has been as
hard physically as it has been successful from a sanitary point of
view. However, the West Coast of South America is now clear from
Panama South, and that is worth all the pain and separation and
privation that it has cost.us both. My Mother died a week before he
left.last February.

I am doing myself the honor to send you a copy of myyfirst
real book--though I have collaborated with Father inaa Malarial
Catechism. I do this mainly to assure you that the feeling that
prompted the ar Poems no only was, but is, far more widely spread
among us than the current press would lead one to believe, and part-
ly as a very inadequate expression of my sincere admiration of your
splendid work, before, during and after the War.
With heartfelt good wishes for the New Year,
